awd_titl_txt: Improving Nitrogen Predictions by Updating Tropospheric Kinetics (INPUT-K)
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to provide alternative estimates of reaction rate coefficients using statistical methods to improve model predictions of atmospheric nitrogen chemistry. This is a demonstration project that will make direct use of field observations to guide further investment in laboratory experiments and reveal mechanisms that can lead to modeling biases. The independent estimates of reaction rates provided by this project will provide an important constraint on estimating the health and climate impacts of reactive nitrogen chemistry.

This project aims to improve model simulations of reactive nitrogen by achieving the following objectives: (1) Apply a previously successful inference modeling framework to a more recent observational campaign (such as the NSF-supported DC3 campaign) where nitrogen imbalances in 3-D models have been shown; (2) Constrain rate coefficients and product stoichiometry in climate relevant environments using likelihood calculations based on reduced model ensembles and observational datasets; and (3) Replace stochastic physical transport with mechanistic transport using an ensemble of simulated air parcel trajectories that are representative of post-convection transport. Together, stochastic modeling, mechanistic chemistry, and high quality observations will be used to supplement laboratory studies and identify reactions for subsequent laboratory investigation.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project integrates field observations with laboratory-based kinetics using a formal statistical method that accounts for uncontrolled variables. Field observations have often provided feedback to kinetic literature, but their usefulness is limited by the many uncontrolled variables in the field. INPUT-K leverages reduced form model and a formal Bayesian inference paradigm to overcome these challenges and make direct estimates of reaction rates. Combining formal Bayesian statistics with the stochastic treatment of uncertain parameters allows for direct use of field observations in the reaction rate literature. However, current findings suggest that by replacing stochastic treatment of air parcel age with trajectory-based transport air parcel removal, a new challenge has been added into the research to constrain physical removing process. Only focusing on gas phase chemistry will not constrain HNO3 chemistry since some of HNO3 could be uptaken into the aerosol phase in the lower temperature upper troposphere. Although current results make it hard to constrain uncertainty from reaction rates, it still provides hints that nitrogen chemistry in current chemical mechanisms is ill-constrained. From a broader perspective, this project strengthens research on short-lived atmospheric pollutants. Short-lived pollutants are estimated by the World Health Organization to contribute to over 7 million deaths annually. The same pollutants associated with mortality are also important to contributors to climate forcing. The influence of gases and aerosols on health and climate are typically estimated from a combination of observations and modeling. Model-based estimates of health and climate show first- and second- order sensitivities. INPUT-K's independent estimates of reaction rates provide an important way to constrain the projections of health and climate.
